questions.question: The minimum size of placards identifying hazardous materials is:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards must be at least 10 and three-quarter inches square.

questions.question: Manhole covers:
questions.answerA: May be open when a vehicle is being driven.
questions.answerB: Should be closed when a vehicle is being driven.
questions.answerD: Should be removed when a vehicle is being driven.
questions.explanation: Be sure to inspect your vehicle before driving. Never drive a tank vehicle with open valves or manhole covers.

questions.question: Before entering a curve, you should:
questions.explanation: Always downshift before entering a curve. Decreasing your speed before entering the curve will allow you to maintain better control over the vehicle throughout the curve.

questions.question: You should always be able to stop within:
questions.answerC: Your view of the road ahead.
questions.answerD: A minute of hitting the brakes.
questions.explanation: You should always make sure that your vehicle will be able to stop within the area of the road that you are able to see. This means that you must slow down whenever conditions reduce visibility.

questions.question: To prevent a rollover, a driver should:
questions.explanation: Rollovers can happen when a combination vehicle is turned too quickly. To help prevent the risk of rollover, it is important to keep the vehicle's center of gravity low by loading cargo as close to the ground as possible.

questions.question: On a shipping paper, if the letter “G” appears in Column 1, what else needs to appear?
questions.answerA: The technical name of the hazardous material
questions.answerB: The type of packaging containing the hazardous material
questions.answerD: The date the product was packed
questions.explanation: If the letter “G,” for "Generic," is written in Column 1 of a shipping paper, the technical name of the associated hazardous material must also be listed.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the items can be distinguished by:
questions.answerA: The hazardous materials being listed first.
questions.answerB: The non-hazardous materials being written in pencil.
questions.answerC: The hazardous materials being listed in red ink.
questions.answerD: The hazardous materials being written larger than the non-hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be distinguished in one of three ways. They must be entered first on the shipping paper, highlighted in a contrasting color, or marked with an "X" in a column titled "HM."

questions.question: Shippers must keep a copy of shipping papers for:
questions.explanation: Shippers must retain a physical copy or an electronic image of hazardous materials shipping papers for a minimum of two years after the materials are accepted by the initial carrier. For hazardous waste, this increases to three years.

questions.question: Skids caused by acceleration can usually be resolved by:
questions.answerB: Taking your foot off the accelerator.
questions.explanation: Skids caused by acceleration can usually be corrected by taking your foot off of the accelerator. If you are on an especially slippery surface, you may also need to push the clutch in.

questions.question: Compared to other commercial motor vehicles, combination vehicles need more space on the road because they are longer and they:
questions.answerA: Need more space to turn and stop.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles need more space on the road than other commercial vehicles because they are longer and need more space to turn and stop. It is especially important to properly manage space when you are operating a combination vehicle.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed to get across the tracks as quickly as possible.
questions.answerB: Roll your window down to listen for a train.
questions.answerD: Never try to outdrive an approaching train.
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed as you approach a railroad crossing. Remember that you will not necessarily be able to hear a train, and don't assume that signals will warn you of its approach. Never try to outdrive an approaching train at a railroad crossing.

questions.question: Rollovers are most likely to happen when:
questions.explanation: Rollovers happen when an operator turns too fast. Drivers should be sure to slow down before entering turns and curves, especially when transporting a fully-loaded rig.

questions.question: Keeping emergency equipment on a bus is:
questions.answerB: Encouraged, especially if there is extra room on the bus.
questions.answerC: Encouraged if there are more than 15 passengers present.
questions.explanation: Commercial vehicles must be equipped with the appropriate emergency equipment. Equipment should include a fire extinguisher, emergency reflectors, and spare fuses, if applicable.

questions.question: If feeling sleepy while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and finish the trip.
questions.answerB: Drive faster to arrive to your destination sooner.
questions.answerC: Leave the road and take a nap.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel sleepy while driving, the only safe response is to stop driving and get some sleep. Attempting to fight off exhaustion is dangerous and a major cause of fatal crashes. Stimulants are not a safe solution because they may help keep you awake but will not make you more alert. Once stimulants wear off, you will be even more tired than you were originally.

questions.question: When traction is poor, a driver should accelerate slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is best to always accelerate very slowly.
questions.answerB: So they do not lose control of their vehicle.
questions.answerC: So the driver does not accelerate faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.answerD: To be the last vehicle through an intersection.
questions.explanation: Speeding up too quickly on a road with poor traction could cause a driver to lose control of their vehicle. In conditions that cause poor traction, a driver should accelerate especially smoothly and gradually.

questions.question: Charter bus passengers should not be allowed to board until departure time because:
questions.answerA: The cost of the bus starts when the first passenger boards. It saves money to board as late as possible.
questions.answerB: Passengers will be more likely to get on and off the bus multiple times before departing, raising the risk that they will miss the departure entirely.
questions.answerC: Passengers should not be allowed to decide which seats to take until the bus is about to leave.
questions.answerD: Waiting to load helps to prevent theft and vandalism.
questions.explanation: To help prevent theft or vandalism, charter bus drivers should not allow passengers to board the vehicle until departure time.

questions.question: Federal and state laws require:
questions.answerA: Drivers to regularly inspect their vehicles.
questions.answerB: Drivers to inspect their vehicles, but only if they believe there may be a problem.
questions.answerC: Drivers to inspect their vehicles if planning to travel out-of-state.
questions.answerD: Drivers to inspect their vehicles, but only if they will be transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Commercial drivers are required by federal and state laws to inspect their vehicles before every trip. Regular inspections can help drivers identify issues before they become dangerous and costly.

questions.question: Texting while driving a CMV is:
questions.answerA: Acceptable if the text is work-related.
questions.answerB: Acceptable if there are fewer than 10 words in the text message.
questions.answerC: Encouraged because it is safer than talking on the phone.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving a commercial motor vehicle is both illegal and dangerous. Manually entering text into or reading text from any electronic device is considered texting.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, a CDL applicant may be asked to:
questions.explanation: While testing for a CDL, an applicant will be required to go through a full vehicle inspection. The vehicle inspection test will include an engine oil level check.

questions.question: When driving through a curve during the skills test, you should:
questions.answerA: Veer from your lane if needed to complete the curve.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed after entering the curve.
questions.answerC: Refrain from looking for other vehicles while turning.
questions.answerD: Reduce your speed before entering the curve.
questions.explanation: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving skills test, you must reduce your speed sufficiently before entering the curve so that you do not need to further brake or shift in the curve. Keep the vehicle in its lane and continue to check for traffic in all directions.

questions.question: An example of mandatory emergency equipment is:
questions.answerA: A supply of spare electrical fuses.
questions.explanation: Mandatory emergency equipment includes: at least one fire extinguisher; spare electrical fuses (unless the vehicle is equipped with circuit breakers); and warning devices for parked vehicles (such as reflective triangles).

questions.question: With your low beam headlights turned on, you should be able to see about ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights allow you to see about 250 feet ahead of your vehicle. When driving at night, adjust your speed so that you will be able to stop in the distance illuminated by your headlights.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of fatigue?
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued is dangerous. Warning signs of fatigue include difficulty focusing; repeated yawning or rubbing of the eyes; daydreaming or wandering thoughts; and drifting out of your lane.

questions.question: Most heavy vehicles require ____ to change gears.
questions.explanation: Most heavy vehicles with manual transmissions require double clutching to change gears. A driver should release the accelerator, push in the clutch, and shift into neutral at the same time. After releasing the clutch and allowing the vehicle to change to the necessary speed, the driver should push in the clutch, shift gears, then simultaneously release the clutch and accelerate.

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.explanation: Factors that can affect your vehicle's stopping distance include driving speed, the vehicle's weight, and the slipperiness of the road surface.

questions.question: When traveling with cargo, you must make sure the cargo is secure:
questions.answerB: Every 150 miles or three hours of driving.
questions.answerC: Only after traveling up a hill.
questions.answerD: Only after coming to a hard stop.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be inspected before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of the trip, and every three hours or 150 miles traveled. The driver of a truck transporting cargo is responsible for the cargo being safely secured throughout the trip.

questions.question: What is black ice?
questions.answerA: A thick layer of ice on the road
questions.answerB: A thin layer of ice on the road
questions.answerC: Ice that is black from debris on the road
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet.

questions.question: Mirror adjustment can only be checked properly if:
questions.answerB: There is no trailer attached to the tractor.
questions.answerC: The vehicle is on a slight incline.
questions.answerD: The vehicle is on a slight decline.
questions.explanation: If a trailer is attached to a tractor, the adjustment of the vehicle's mirrors can only be checked accurately if the trailer is straight.

questions.question: Which of the following surfaces provides the least amount of traction?
questions.explanation: Be especially cautious when driving on ice that has begun to melt. Ice that is wet is much more slippery than ice that is dry.

questions.question: When starting the vehicle during the pre-trip inspection, the coolant temperature should:
questions.explanation: After starting your vehicle during the pre-trip inspection, you should watch the gauges. The coolant temperature should gradually rise to a normal operating range.

questions.question: When exiting your vehicle, you:
questions.answerA: Must maintain four points of contact with the vehicle.
questions.answerB: May turn to face the road before your exit is complete.
questions.answerC: Must be facing away from the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: If there are no warning gates or lights at a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Not worry because the tracks are likely abandoned.
questions.answerB: Park your vehicle and walk up to the tracks to determine if a train is approaching.
questions.answerC: Look down the tracks in both directions to ensure that no trains are approaching.
questions.answerD: Do whatever surrounding vehicles are doing.
questions.explanation: A passive railroad crossing is a crossing that lacks control devices, like gates or warning lights. Before crossing a passive railroad crossing, you should search the tracks for approaching trains coming from either direction.

questions.question: When inspecting the exhaust system, which of the following should not cause concern?
questions.answerD: Exhaust system parts that are not rubbing against fuel system parts
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle's exhaust system, be alert to a number of potential problems, including loose, broken, or missing exhaust pipes, mufflers, tailpipes, or vertical stacks; loose, broken, or missing mounting brackets, clamps, bolts, or nuts; exhaust system parts rubbing against fuel system parts, tires, or other moving parts of the vehicle; and exhaust system parts that are leaking.

questions.question: Distracted drivers may be:
questions.answerC: Preoccupied with using their cell phones.
questions.answerD: Not talking to anyone else in their vehicles.
questions.explanation: You may be able to tell that another driver is distracted if you can see them drifting within a lane or across lane dividers; traveling at inconsistent speeds; being preoccupied with a cell phone, a map, food, or other items; or engaging in conversation with passengers.

questions.question: A fatigued driver:
questions.answerB: Should take over-the-counter remedies to wake them up.
questions.answerC: May make critical decisions too slowly.
questions.answerD: Is usually more conscientious than a typical driver.
questions.explanation: If you are fatigued, you will not see or react to hazards as quickly as you would if you were fully energized and awake. You will be impaired in making critical decisions.

questions.question: Keeping emergency equipment on a bus is:
questions.answerB: Encouraged, especially if there is extra room on the bus.
questions.answerC: Encouraged if there are more than 15 passengers present.
questions.explanation: Commercial vehicles must be equipped with the appropriate emergency equipment. Equipment should include a fire extinguisher, emergency reflectors, and spare fuses, if applicable.

questions.question: While driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Develop plans to get out of any dangerous situation that could arise.
questions.answerD: Focus on your own driving and not worry about other drivers.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should consistently check the road ahead for hazards. Develop a plan to deal with any hazards that could arise.

questions.question: How does doubling your speed from 20 mph to 40 mph affect your vehicle's braking distance?
questions.explanation: Increasing your vehicle's speed will increase your vehicle's striking power and braking distance. Doubling your vehicle's speed from 20 to 40 mph will multiply its braking distance by four.

questions.question: A curve's posted design speed is:
questions.answerB: Safe for all vehicles, including buses.
questions.answerC: The minimum speed at which the curve should be driven.
questions.explanation: Even under ideal weather conditions, a bus being driven at the posted design speed for a curve could either roll over or slide off the road. For safety, you should reduce your speed before driving a bus around a curve.

questions.question: The driver’s seat of a bus should include:
questions.answerA: A pocket for storage on its left side.
questions.answerB: A pocket for storage on its right side.
questions.explanation: The driver's seat on a bus must be equipped with a seat belt, which the driver should always use.

questions.question: When arriving at a destination, it is best to remind exiting passengers to take their carry-on bags with them:
questions.explanation: Before a bus is brought to a complete stop at its destination, it is best for the driver to remind exiting passengers to take their carry-ons with them.

questions.question: The front of an enclosed trailer should:
questions.explanation: When inspecting an enclosed trailer as a part of the vehicle inspection test, check the front area of the trailer for signs of damage, such as cracks, bulges, or holes.

questions.question: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Check traffic thoroughly in all directions.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed before entering the curve.
questions.answerC: Keep your vehicle in its lane.
questions.answerD: Steadily use the brakes throughout the curve.
questions.explanation: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving test, you should thoroughly check traffic in all directions. Before entering the curve, reduce your speed sufficiently so that further braking or shifting is not required. Keep your vehicle in its lane and continue checking traffic in all directions.

questions.question: The standee line:
questions.answerA: Is a line on the floor of a bus that passengers may not cross.
questions.answerB: Is a single-file line of standing passengers.
questions.answerC: Shows the maximum number of people allowed on a bus.
questions.answerD: Shows how tall the passengers on a bus may be.
questions.explanation: While a bus is traveling, passengers may not stand any farther forward than the rear of the driver's seat. To mark this barrier, a bus that is designed to allow passengers to stand must have a two-inch line on the floor (or some other means of showing passengers where they cannot stand). This is known as the standee line.

questions.question: Which of the following is not acceptable emergency equipment?
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will need to show emergency equipment, including spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and a properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: If an aggressive driver is involved in a crash on the road ahead of you, you should:
questions.answerA: Block the driver in with your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Stop after the crash scene and report the driver’s aggressive behavior to the police.
questions.answerC: Continue driving and mind your own business.
questions.answerD: Pull over and yell at the driver.
questions.explanation: If you observe a crash involving an aggressive driver, you should stop a safe distance from the crash scene, wait for police to arrive, and inform them of the aggressive behavior you witnessed.

questions.question: Regarding winter driving, all of the following are true, except:
questions.answerA: Front tires should have a tread depth of at least 4/32 an inch.
questions.answerC: Rear tires should have a tread depth of at least 2/32 an inch.
questions.answerD: Use a gauge to verify that each tire has a safe tread depth.
questions.explanation: When driving during the winter, it is particularly important that your tires have adequate tread. You need a tread depth of at least 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires, and at least 2/32 of an inch on the back tires. Check the tread depths by using a gauge.

questions.question: If pulled off to the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Allow your taillights to alert other motorists.
questions.answerB: Turn on your emergency flashers to warn other motorists.
questions.answerC: Keep your lights off to avoid distracting other motorists.
questions.answerD: Keep your door open to warn other motorists.
questions.explanation: If you must stop and park on the side of the road, make sure to turn on your emergency flashers. This is especially important at night. Taillights are not an adequate when alerting other drivers because the drivers may mistakenly think your vehicle is moving normally and collide with it.

questions.question: An example of mandatory emergency equipment is:
questions.answerA: A supply of spare electrical fuses.
questions.explanation: Mandatory emergency equipment includes: at least one fire extinguisher; spare electrical fuses (unless the vehicle is equipped with circuit breakers); and warning devices for parked vehicles (such as reflective triangles).

questions.question: Drivers are usually the least alert:
questions.explanation: Drivers are usually less alert when driving at night, especially after midnight.

questions.question: The maximum amount of play that is safe on a 20-inch steering wheel is:
questions.explanation: A steering wheel with play of more than 10 degrees may be defective. On a 20-inch wheel, this is equal to about two inches of movement at the rim of the wheel.

questions.question: During exercises that are not the straight line backing exercise, you may exit your vehicle to check its position no more than:
questions.explanation: A driver is allowed to exit their vehicle to check its position during any basic control skills test exercise. This action is called a "look." During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: How should you test the low pressure warning signal?
questions.answerA: Engage and disable the parking brake.
questions.answerB: Rapidly press and release the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Uncouple and recouple all glad hands.
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light functions properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: The application pressure gauge:
questions.answerA: Shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: Shows the temperature of air being used in the braking system.
questions.answerC: Shows the pressure of the air coming from the compressor.
questions.answerD: Shows the number of times the brakes have been used.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. Not all vehicles with an air brake system have this gauge.

questions.question: In a newer vehicle, you apply the parking brake:
questions.answerA: By using a diamond-shaped yellow knob.
questions.answerB: By using a round red knob.
questions.answerC: By using a square green knob.
questions.answerD: By using a black round knob.
questions.explanation: In a newer vehicle with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a diamond-shaped yellow knob. The knob is pulled out to apply the parking brakes and pushed in to release them.

questions.question: The ____ tells a driver how much pressure is in the air tanks.
questions.explanation: A vehicle that is equipped with air brakes must also be equipped with a supply pressure gauge. This gauge tells the driver how much air pressure is in each of the vehicle's air tanks.

questions.question: The air compressor governor controls:
questions.answerA: When the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: How fast air is pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: The temperature of air pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: If braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add ____ to your vehicle's total stopping distance.
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to a vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: What kind of force must emergency brakes use?
questions.explanation: Because air pressure can eventually leak away, the emergency brakes in an air brake system must be held on by mechanical force.

questions.question: An air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately ____ to come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: A vehicle's total stopping distance is made up of perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. With all of these factors included, an air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately 450 feet to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: When you need to stop in an emergency, you should:
questions.answerA: Lock the wheels and skid to a stop.
questions.answerB: Stop in a way that keeps your vehicle in a straight line.
questions.answerC: Stop in a way that turns your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Expect your vehicle to slow down more quickly than usual.
questions.explanation: If you need to make an emergency stop, you can use either the controlled braking method or the stab braking method. It's important to brake in a way that keeps your vehicle traveling in a straight line while still allowing you to turn, if necessary.

questions.question: Before a vehicle with dual air brakes is driven, pressure of at least ____ should be built up in both braking systems.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up pressure of at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: The brake pedal is part of which braking system?
questions.explanation: The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when a driver presses the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you must wait for the air compressor to build a minimum of ____ in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for the air compressor to build up at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: What color are ABS malfunction lamps?
questions.explanation: Vehicles with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lamps.

questions.question: What does ABS do?
questions.answerB: Prevent the air compressor from overheating
questions.answerC: Prevent the front brakes from being used on ice
questions.answerD: Prevent the brakes from being used if downshifting would be more effective
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent wheels from locking up during hard applications of the brakes, especially on slippery surfaces.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: What does the air compressor governor do?
questions.answerA: Controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: Controls how quickly air leaves the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: Controls the temperature of the air entering the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Controls the temperature of the air leaving the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: What do anti-lock brakes do?
questions.answerA: Help a driver avoid wheel lockup
questions.answerC: Prevent a vehicle from accelerating while traveling uphill
questions.answerD: Prevent a vehicle from accelerating while traveling downhill
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent the vehicle's wheels from locking up from hard brake application.

questions.question: If the air pressure warning light comes on, you should:
questions.answerB: Activate your hazard lights and continue driving.
questions.answerC: Call the local law enforcement agency.
questions.answerD: Safely exit the roadway and stop.
questions.explanation: If the air pressure warning light or buzzer comes on while you are driving, you should immediately stop and safely park the vehicle. This warning signal indicates that there is a problem in the air brake system that needs to be fixed.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A single vehicle with air brakes should have a leakage rate no higher than 3 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: On trucks and buses, where are ABS malfunction lamps located?
questions.answerC: On the outside of the vehicle by the passenger’s door
questions.explanation: Tractors, trucks, and buses with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lamps located on their instrument panels. Trailers have yellow ABS malfunction lamps on their left side, either on the front or rear corner.

questions.question: If the brake pads rub against the brake drums and create too much heat:
questions.answerB: The brakes will become extra sensitive.
questions.answerD: The air compressor will kick on to cool the brakes.
questions.explanation: Brakes heat up with use. If they are overused and become too hot, expansion and chemical changes will make them less effective and eventually cause them to stop working altogether. This is known as "brake fade."

questions.question: To stop in a vehicle that uses air brakes, the driver should:
questions.explanation: To make a normal stop in a vehicle with air brakes, push the brake pedal down. The harder the pedal is pressed, the more air pressure is released.

questions.question: The emergency brake system uses:
questions.answerA: Only parts of the parking brake system.
questions.answerB: Only parts of the service brake system.
questions.answerC: Parts of both the parking and service brake systems.
questions.answerD: Only parts unique to the emergency brake system.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, there are three different braking systems: a service brake system, a parking brake system, and an emergency brake system. The emergency brake system uses parts of both the parking and service brake systems.

questions.question: When only the tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: There is a decreased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerB: There is an increased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerC: The brakes will not work as effectively as they would without ABS.
questions.answerD: The brakes will become more sensitive.
questions.explanation: If a tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) but the trailer is not, the risk of jackknifing will be reduced and the driver should still be able to maintain steering control. If only the trailer is equipped with ABS, it is less likely that the trailer will swing out to one side.

questions.question: If the low pressure warning light comes on while you are driving:
questions.answerA: Braking will only occur if there is enough air in the tanks.
questions.answerB: You can brake 14 times before the air in the system runs out.
questions.answerC: You should continue to drive normally and check the brake system when it is convenient.
questions.answerD: You should continue driving, but turn the emergency flashers on to warn other motorists.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning light turns on, you should stop and safely park your vehicle as soon as possible. Controlled braking will be possible only as long as enough air remains in the tanks.

questions.question: On trucks and buses, where are ABS malfunction lamps located?
questions.answerC: On the outside of the vehicle by the passenger’s door
questions.explanation: Tractors, trucks, and buses with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lamps located on their instrument panels. Trailers have yellow ABS malfunction lamps on their left side, either on the front or rear corner.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you must wait for the air compressor to build a minimum of ____ in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for the air compressor to build up at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks have an air pressure level of:
questions.explanation: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks are at an air pressure level of 125 psi. This air pressure level is referred to as the "cut-out" level.

questions.question: Brake fading is caused when:
questions.answerA: Brakes are not used often enough.
questions.explanation: Using the brakes excessively will cause them to overheat, making them less effective. This is referred to as "fading."

questions.question: All air tanks must include:
questions.explanation: Air brake system tanks must contain drain valves. These valves are used to drain accumulated oil and water from the tanks and may be either manually or automatically operated.

questions.question: Brakes may get out of adjustment:
questions.explanation: Brakes can get out of adjustment quickly, especially if they are used to the point of overheating. Brake adjustment should be checked frequently.

questions.question: Spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: When too much air pressure is lost.
questions.answerB: When a control on the dashboard is activated.
questions.answerC: When the tires have minimal tread depth.
questions.explanation: Spring brakes come on automatically when air pressure drops to an unsafe psi level. Instead of waiting for the spring brakes to automatically activate, you should safely exit the road as soon as you notice the low pressure warning signal and bring your vehicle to a stop while you are still able to control the brakes.

questions.question: An air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately ____ to come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: A vehicle's total stopping distance is made up of perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. With all of these factors included, an air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately 450 feet to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A single vehicle with air brakes should have a leakage rate no higher than 3 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: Test the low pressure warning signal:
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light function properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: Dollies equipped with ABS are required to have malfunction lamps located where?
questions.explanation: A dolly equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is required to have a yellow malfunction lamp located on its left side.

questions.question: The most common type of foundation brake used is the:
questions.explanation: The most common type of foundation brake is an s-cam drum brake.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter the tank.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and compressor oil from the air tank.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks must be drained to remove accumulated water and compressor oil. Failing to do so can cause damage. Manually operated drains should be used at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerB: Exit the road and park as soon as safely possible.
questions.answerC: Stop where you are and park.
questions.answerD: Put on your hazard lights and continue driving.
questions.explanation: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, it is important that you safely exit the roadway as soon as possible and park your vehicle. If the air pressure gets too low, the brakes will no longer work well enough for you to stop safely.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a part of an air brake system?
questions.explanation: Air brakes consists of three separate braking systems: the service brake system, the parking brake system, and the emergency brake system.

questions.question: How is the parking brake released?
questions.answerA: By tapping the brake pedal three times
questions.answerB: By pushing in the brake control knob
questions.explanation: In vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a knob. The knob is pulled out to apply the brakes, and pushed in to release them.

questions.question: When only the tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: There is a decreased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerB: There is an increased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerC: The brakes will not work as effectively as they would without ABS.
questions.answerD: The brakes will become more sensitive.
questions.explanation: If a tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) but the trailer is not, the risk of jackknifing will be reduced and the driver should still be able to maintain steering control. If only the trailer is equipped with ABS, it is less likely that the trailer will swing out to one side.

questions.question: The air compressor governor controls:
questions.answerA: When the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: How fast air is pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: The temperature of air pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: Why do you need to drain air tanks regularly?
questions.answerA: Because the air gets old and needs to be replaced
questions.answerB: Because compressed air contains some water which must be drained from the tanks
questions.answerC: To allow for a change in air pressure
questions.answerD: To remove bad air from the tanks
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Tanks must be drained regularly to remove this build-up.

questions.question: The parking brake should be:
questions.answerA: Used whenever you park your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Set when driving in bad weather.
questions.explanation: The parking brake in a vehicle with air brakes should be used every time the vehicle is parked.

questions.question: To use the stab braking method in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up, release the brakes until the wheels start rolling, then repeat the process.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes about halfway, but keep the wheels rolling.
questions.answerC: Fully apply the brakes, let the wheels lock up, and hold the brake pedal down, keeping the wheels locked until the vehicle stops.
questions.explanation: The stab braking method for emergency stops involves fully applying the brakes until they lock up. The brakes are then released until the wheels start rolling, then the process is repeated.

questions.question: Some air brake systems use alcohol:
questions.answerA: To reduce the risk of ice forming in air brake valves.
questions.answerB: To make the compressor run more efficiently.
questions.answerC: To lubricate parts of the braking system.
questions.answerD: To reduce the risk of rust forming on air brake valves.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems contain an alcohol evaporator. This device introduces alcohol into the braking system to inhibit the formation of ice.

questions.question: When you press the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air pressure pushes out the rod and moves the:
questions.explanation: When pressing the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air will enter the brake chambers. The added air pressure will push out the rods and move slack adjusters, twisting the brake camshafts.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes that were built on or after March 1, 1997 are equipped with:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes that were manufactured on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). ABS is required in any other type of vehicle with air brakes that was manufactured on or after March 1, 1998.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use:
questions.explanation: Most heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems, in which there are two separate braking systems operated by a single set of controls. Each system operates the brakes on different axles.

questions.question: When connecting a converter dolly to a second or third trailer, the trailer height should be:
questions.answerA: Slightly higher than the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerB: Level with the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerC: Slightly lower than the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerD: Next to the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: When connecting a converter dolly to a second or third trailer, the trailer height should be correct. It should be slightly lower than the center of the fifth wheel.

questions.question: Before a drive, ensure that air flows to all trailers by:
questions.answerA: Opening the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerB: Closing the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerC: Disconnecting air supply lines and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerD: Rolling each trailer down a hill and testing the brakes.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that air in the air brake system reaches all trailers. Do this by waiting for air pressure to build, then sending air to both the emergency and service lines and opening the shut-off valves on the rear of the last trailer. If air escapes from the shut-off valves in the rear of the combination, the air is being supplied to the entire vehicle.

questions.question: What is another name for the service line?
questions.explanation: The service line, also called the control line or signal line, carries air to the trailer brakes and is controlled by the foot brake or trailer hand brake.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerC: Makes it easier to turn a large vehicle.
questions.answerD: Assists with the operation of brake lights.
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up during hard braking.

questions.question: Having ABS on only one axle:
questions.answerA: Does not change braking in any way.
questions.answerC: Will allow the driver additional control over their vehicle when braking.
questions.answerD: Will cause extra strain on the other axles.
questions.explanation: Having an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) on only the trailer, or even on just one axle, will still provide a driver with additional control over the trailer when braking.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve:
questions.answerA: Should always be used for parking.
questions.answerB: Should only be used for parking on a downhill.
questions.answerC: Should never be used for parking.
questions.answerD: Should only be used when transporting cargo.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve should not be used for parking. This could cause all of the air to leak out of the braking system, resulting in the brakes releasing. Instead, use the parking brake.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when:
questions.answerA: A truck driver is driving too fast.
questions.answerB: The driver of a vehicle in front of a truck is moving to slowly.
questions.answerC: A truck driver is driving too slowly.
questions.explanation: Rollovers happen when a vehicle is driven too fast. To reduce the risk of rollover, make sure the weight of cargo is loaded low to the ground, and that you take turns and curves slowly.

questions.question: After connecting the air lines to the trailer while coupling, you should:
questions.explanation: Correctly following the steps to couple and uncouple trailers is vital to safely operating a combination vehicle. After connecting the air lines to the trailer while coupling, you should supply air to the trailer.

questions.question: A combination vehicle has:
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles have two air lines: a service line and an emergency line.

questions.question: If a trailer is too high:
questions.answerA: It will not make a difference when coupling.
questions.explanation: Before coupling together a tractor and a trailer, you should make sure the trailer is at the proper height. If the trailer is too low, the trailer nose may be damaged. If the trailer is too high, it may not be able to couple correctly.

questions.question: Trailers with low underneath clearance may be difficult to drive:
questions.explanation: Railroad-highway crossings may be difficult to cross when pulling a trailer with a low underneath clearance. In particular, both low-slung units and single-axle tractors pulling long trailers are especially challenging to drive over raised crossings.

questions.question: Combination vehicles:
questions.answerA: Are usually shorter than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerB: Are usually lighter than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerC: Require more skill to drive than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerD: Are easier to drive than single commercial vehicles.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles are usually heavier and longer than single commercial vehicles. For these reasons, they usually require more driving skill than single commercial vehicles.

questions.question: What is off-tracking?
questions.answerA: When a vehicle’s front wheels follow a different path than its rear wheels
questions.answerB: When a vehicle's wheels all follow the exact same path
questions.answerC: When a load shifts during a turn
questions.answerD: When a vehicle's wheels run over a curb during a turn
questions.explanation: When a vehicle goes around a corner, the rear wheels follow a different path than the front wheels. This is known as off-tracking, or "cheating."

questions.question: When backing up to couple a trailer, you should position the tractor:
questions.answerA: At a 90-degree angle in front of the trailer.
questions.answerB: Directly in front of the trailer.
questions.answerC: At a 30-degree angle in front of the trailer.
questions.answerD: At a 60-degree angle in front of the trailer.
questions.explanation: When backing up to couple a trailer, you should position the tractor directly in front of the trailer. Trying to couple while backing at an angle could cause the trailer to move and the landing gear to break.

questions.question: When coupling a trailer:
questions.answerA: Make sure to couple matching glad hands.
questions.answerB: Any glad hand can be connected to any other glad hand.
questions.answerC: It is best to leave one glad hand unattached.
questions.answerD: Only one set of glad hands should be connected.
questions.explanation: When coupling, make sure you couple matching glad hands. They are often color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: Proper coupling technique:
questions.answerA: Is the same on all vehicles.
questions.answerB: Is essential to the safe operation of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Includes ensuring that the fifth wheel plate is not greased.
questions.explanation: Knowing proper coupling and uncoupling technique is fundamental to the safe operation of combination vehicles. Improper coupling can be very dangerous.

questions.question: After finishing a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerC: Leave the emergency line valve open.
questions.answerD: Leave the rear shut-off valves open.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should ensure that air reaches all air brakes on all trailers by opening up the rear emergency line and service line shut-off valves to listen for escaping air. Close both shut-off valves before beginning to drive.

questions.question: Fully-loaded rigs:
questions.answerA: Are less likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerB: Are more likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerC: Are just as likely to roll over as empty rigs.
questions.explanation: Because the weight of cargo gives them a higher center of gravity, fully-loaded rigs are 10 times more likely to roll over in a crash than empty rigs.

questions.question: Pull out the trailer air supply control to test:
questions.explanation: Be sure to test the trailer emergency brakes before beginning a trip. After ensuring that the trailer rolls freely, you can test the emergency brakes by pulling out the trailer air supply control, or placing it in the "emergency" position. Pull forward slightly with the tractor and make sure the trailer does not move.

questions.question: A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause:
questions.answerB: The tractor protection valve to close.
questions.answerC: The rear trailer to detach from the combination.
questions.explanation: The tractor protection valve keeps air in the trailer's braking system should the trailer break away or develop a leak. A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause the tractor protection valve to open and the emergency trailer brakes to activate.

questions.question: When driving a bobtail tractor, you should be aware that:
questions.answerB: Bobtails cannot drive as fast as tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerC: Bobtails are more difficult to stop than tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerD: Bobtails are illegal in most states.
questions.explanation: Bobtail tractors are tractors that are not attached to any semitrailers. When operating a bobtail, you should be aware that stopping can be difficult and that it will take a longer distance to bring the bobtail to a complete stop than it would a tractor attached to a loaded semitrailer.

questions.question: If oil and water build up in your vehicle's air tanks, the brakes:
questions.explanation: Air tanks should be drained daily to remove water and oil buildup. An excess of oil and water in the air tanks can interfere with proper brake function.

questions.question: If you are operating a vehicle built before 1998 and are unsure if the trailer has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can:
questions.answerA: Check for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Look for a red light on the front right corner of the converter dolly.
questions.answerC: Pump the air brakes to activate the ABS.
questions.explanation: If you are operating a vehicle built before 1998 and are unsure if the trailer has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can check under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: A tractor protection valve is:
questions.answerA: A device that keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system, should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak.
questions.answerC: A device that controls fuel levels.
questions.answerD: A device that allows the battery to recharge efficiently.
questions.explanation: On combination vehicles with air brakes, the tractor protection valve keeps air in the tractor or truck brake system, should the trailer develop a bad leak or break away from the tractor.

questions.question: Using the trailer hand valve while driving:
questions.explanation: Never use the trailer hand valve while operating your vehicle. Using the trailer hand valve while driving can cause your trailer to skid.

questions.question: What is another name for the service line?
questions.explanation: The service line, also called the control line or signal line, carries air to the trailer brakes and is controlled by the foot brake or trailer hand brake.

questions.question: Which type of vehicle is most prone to the “crack-the-whip” effect?
questions.explanation: Triple combination trailers are most vulnerable to the "crack-the-whip" effect.

questions.question: When backing a trailer, how should you turn the steering wheel?
questions.answerA: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction you want the trailer to go.
questions.answerB: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want the trailer to go.
questions.answerD: It depends on where the trailer is being backed.
questions.explanation: When backing with a trailer, turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want to go. Once the trailer begins turning, you should then switch the direction of the steering wheel to follow the trailer.

questions.question: Proper coupling technique:
questions.answerA: Is the same on all vehicles.
questions.answerB: Is essential to the safe operation of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Includes ensuring that the fifth wheel plate is not greased.
questions.explanation: Knowing proper coupling and uncoupling technique is fundamental to the safe operation of combination vehicles. Improper coupling can be very dangerous.

questions.question: Simply changing lanes can cause:
questions.answerA: A “crack-the-whip” effect, resulting in a rollover.
questions.answerC: Confusion over which lane the driver is hoping to use.
questions.answerD: Other drivers to reduce their speed.
questions.explanation: Due to the "crack-the-whip" effect caused by rearward amplification, changing lanes too quickly in a combination vehicle can result in a rollover.

questions.question: Fully-loaded rigs:
questions.answerA: Are less likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerB: Are more likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerC: Are just as likely to roll over as empty rigs.
questions.explanation: Because the weight of cargo gives them a higher center of gravity, fully-loaded rigs are 10 times more likely to roll over in a crash than empty rigs.

questions.question: Rollovers are most likely to happen when:
questions.explanation: Rollovers happen when an operator turns too fast. Drivers should be sure to slow down before entering turns and curves, especially when transporting a fully-loaded rig.

questions.question: An air supply control lever should be in its "normal" position when you are:
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "normal" position, it is properly set for you to pull a trailer.

questions.question: If you need to back your trailer but cannot back up in a straight path, you should:
questions.answerC: Swerve back and forth while backing.
questions.explanation: If you need to back your trailer but cannot back up in a straight path, you should back on a curved path toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This will permit you the best possible visibility while backing.

questions.question: When traveling more slowly than 40 mph, maintain at least ____ of following distance per every 10 feet of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: At speeds below 40 mph, you should allow at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle. Follow the same formula when traveling at faster speeds, then add one additional second to your following distance. Remember that larger vehicles require more space to stop than smaller vehicles.

questions.question: A combination vehicle has:
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles have two air lines: a service line and an emergency line.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve:
questions.answerA: Should always be used for parking.
questions.answerB: Should only be used for parking on a downhill.
questions.answerC: Should never be used for parking.
questions.answerD: Should only be used when transporting cargo.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve should not be used for parking. This could cause all of the air to leak out of the braking system, resulting in the brakes releasing. Instead, use the parking brake.

questions.question: What happens when the wheels of a trailer lock up?
questions.answerA: The trailer will usually continue to move in a straight line.
questions.answerC: The trailer will likely swing around.
questions.explanation: A trailer tends to swing around, potentially resulting in a trailer jackknife, if its wheels lock up.

questions.question: When connecting a converter dolly to a second or third trailer, the trailer height should be:
questions.answerA: Slightly higher than the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerB: Level with the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerC: Slightly lower than the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerD: Next to the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: When connecting a converter dolly to a second or third trailer, the trailer height should be correct. It should be slightly lower than the center of the fifth wheel.

questions.question: Before backing your tractor under the trailer, make sure your trailer brakes are:
questions.explanation: Correctly following the steps to couple and uncouple trailers is vital to safely operating a combination vehicle. Before backing your tractor under the trailer while coupling, make sure your trailer brakes are locked.
